etymology.description: pictogram: snake; later borrowed (rebus) for the third-person pronoun; the ‘snake’ sense is now written 蛇.
etymology.interpretation: Originally depicted a snake, then was repurposed as a rebus for a pronoun pronounced tā. The lexical meaning ‘snake’ was reassigned to 蛇, while 它 remained as the third-person neuter pronoun.

examples.chinese: 我看到一只猫(我看到一隻貓)，它很可爱(它很可愛)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ kàn dào yì zhī māo, tā hěn kě'ài.
examples.english: I saw a cat; it is very cute.

examples.chinese: 请把手机给我(請把手機給我)，我需要用它(我需要用它)。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng bǎ shǒujī gěi wǒ, wǒ xūyào yòng tā.
examples.english: Please give me the phone; I need to use it.

examples.chinese: 这台机器坏了(這台機器壞了)，我们得修理它(我們得修理它)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè tái jīqì huài le, wǒmen děi xiūlǐ tā.
examples.english: This machine is broken; we have to fix it.
